claim: Men can prevent premature baldness by shaving their head to avoid it.

supporting.text: Shaving the head does not prevent the biological processes that cause baldness, such as androgenetic alopecia.

attacks.text: Shaving the head does not prevent the biological processes that cause baldness, such as androgenetic alopecia.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing thinning hair before it becomes visibly noticeable.
The illusion of preventing baldness through shaving does not address the underlying biological causes, making it a superficial solution.
Shaving the head may reduce stress-related hair loss by simplifying hair care routines and reducing psychological stress about balding.
Stress-related hair loss is distinct from androgenetic alopecia, and shaving does not impact the genetic factors responsible for the latter.

supporting.text: Baldness is primarily caused by genetic and hormonal factors, which are unaffected by shaving the head.

attacks.text: Baldness is primarily caused by genetic and hormonal factors, which are unaffected by shaving the head.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing thinning hair before it becomes visibly patchy.
The illusion does not address the underlying genetic or hormonal causes, making it a temporary and superficial solution.
Some studies suggest scalp stimulation (e.g., from shaving) may improve blood circulation and slow hair loss.
No conclusive evidence links scalp stimulation from shaving to significant changes in genetic or hormonal hair loss mechanisms.

supporting.text: Shaving the head removes existing hair but does not stop the underlying hair follicles from miniaturizing or ceasing to produce hair.

attacks.text: Shaving the head removes existing hair but does not stop the underlying hair follicles from miniaturizing or ceasing to produce hair.
Shaving the head can reduce mechanical stress on hair follicles, potentially slowing hair loss.
Mechanical stress reduction from shaving is negligible compared to genetic and hormonal factors causing baldness.
Shaving creates the illusion of thicker hair regrowth, making baldness less noticeable.
Illusion of thicker regrowth is temporary and does not address the progressive nature of follicle miniaturization.

supporting.text: Premature baldness is a medical condition related to hair follicle sensitivity to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which shaving does not address.

attacks.text: Premature baldness is a medical condition related to hair follicle sensitivity to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which shaving does not address.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing thinning hair before it becomes visibly patchy.
The illusion does not change the underlying biological process of hair follicle miniaturization caused by DHT.
Shaving may reduce scalp irritation and improve hair health, indirectly slowing hair loss.
There is no scientific evidence that scalp irritation significantly contributes to DHT-induced hair loss.

supporting.text: Shaving the head may give the appearance of avoiding baldness by removing thinning hair, but it does not prevent the progression of hair loss.

attacks.text: Shaving the head may give the appearance of avoiding baldness by removing thinning hair, but it does not prevent the progression of hair loss.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of thicker hair when it regrows, which might psychologically reduce stress-related hair loss.
Stress-related hair loss is a minor factor compared to genetic predisposition, so the psychological effect is negligible in preventing baldness.
Shaving the head can improve scalp hygiene, potentially reducing conditions like dandruff that may contribute to hair loss.
While scalp hygiene is important, there is no strong evidence linking dandruff to permanent hair loss in men.
